Its location is also fantastic - walking distance to the Macau and Kowloon ferry terminals, plus the MTR, plus main shopping strip etc. If you want to relax in your hotel room a lot during your trip you might want to go for somewhere further out and bigger but we were up and out everyday so it was perfect for us. If you are travelling alone and can afford it we would recommend going for a double room to give you a bit more space (based on the reviews of the single rooms) It is also in an area that still has a really Chinese/ Old Hong Kong feel and smell. In 2007 we stayed at a place in New York that wasn't hugely bigger for 5 times the price of MoW.

Reviews.Title: “Mingle Gave Us Headaches”
Reviews.Author: deighter
Reviews.Content: The Mingle rooms look great in the promo photos, but they are actually terribly small -- even the "upgraded" suites. There is no place to put large suitcases, and the only place for cosmetics or bath items is a tiny 2" wide shelf running under the bathroom mirror. Both the bath mirror and the mirror on the wall between the bathroom and the bed are useless. Why? Poor lighting design... it is extremely difficult to shave or apply makeup. We had endless problems with the music player//tv// sound system. The front desk people were very helpful, but they had to come to the room every day to fix something. Terrible. The Mingle looks like it would be the place for sophisticated travelers, but beware, it is not. Rather if you can live out a backpack, have no need for personal grooming, and are happy in a room that you cannot even turn around in because it is so small, then the Mingle might be for you. Noise Warning: Loud construction noise up and down the street until at least April, 2009. But then again, you may find the sound of jackhammers at 8 a.m. pleasant. We did not. That's why we moved over to the Stanford Hillview, to enjoy a real large room, for the same price.

Reviews.Title: “Great location, good value, tiny room but free wi-fi in HK”
Reviews.Author: cUb4
Reviews.Content: Right down the street from the Sheung Wan A2 exit with three late night conveniences stores nearby. Also taxis always going through the intersection to get to the harbour. Coffee shop advertised on the website was closed. Room (12th floor) very small (the shower is wider than the hallway), little awkward to store and move around, and never figured out how to unplug the sink (service had to do it). Had issues operating the TV and the 'technological settings'. But clean, convenient, free wi-fi and for the price, excellent value (booked on hotelclub.com). Hotel will want a $500HKG deposit up front which is returned at the end. If you're not planning to spend a lot of the time in the room, it's well-located (no issues coming back late) and in a interesting area (traditional herb/medicine shops instead of mega malls).

Reviews.Title: “An unexpected pleasant surprise”
Reviews.Author: janda0808
Reviews.Content: After spending a miserable day at another hotel, I didn't have much hope for Mingle on the Wing - I just wanted to leave Hong Kong asap. However, Mingle on the Wing turned out to be much better than I expected and I truely enjoyed my stay with them. The first thing I noticed was the location. WOW! The hotel is extremely close to a MTR stataion. Unlike the other hotel, this time I only had to walk for 30 seconds after leaving the MTR station, and that is great for me as I had 3 big luggages. The lady at the reception (Matty) was very polite, very friendly and extremely helpful. As my room wasn't ready, she asked me to leave my luggages behind her desk and she even carefully labelled all my bags for me. After a good walk around the hotel area, I came back to the hotel and was able to check in before the actual check-in time. My room was on the 8th floor and I was totally blown away when I first saw it. First of all, the door was locked electronically with a magnetic card so I felt safe inside the room (unlike the other hotel which only uses hand locks). The intensity of all lights were controlled by an electronic switch on the wall so you don't have to spend time looking for different switches. You can also choose whether you would like room services on the switch which was cool. The room was elegant, posh and sparkling clean with a foot rest and I was able to use the free high speed internet like they said. The room also had a 37" LCD TV, a fridge and a big open window. I actually booked and paid for a single room, but Matty managed to upgrade me to a bigger room with a double bed. The toilet was very clean with all the supplies I needed (the other hotel didn't even give me a soap). And there were two strong showers for me to choose from, rain-type and normal - I used both! There were other facilities that I didn't use so I can't comment on them, but they all looked very good: DVD player, Cordless IP Phone with Skype, Free Wi-Fi & In-room Surround Sound System. I would like to thank Mingle on the Wing to make my stay so enjoyable, so enjoyable that I had to come and give them a good review on tripadvisor.com. Lastly, thank you so much Matty for your unbeatable customer service - you are a star and you deserve a huge pay rise!! Would I come back to Mingle on the Wing again? Absolutely, and I am telling all my friends to stay there too! :-)

Reviews.Title: “value for money, worth it”
Reviews.Author: Tayug
Reviews.Content: as expected a small hotel, lite room, but worth every cent, great location, next to MTR, walk to CBD, free broadband, both wired & wireless staff were friendly, all facilities in room, bathroom 100% clean etc agree room are very small, but will stay again there next month

Reviews.Title: “Attractive hotel, but too many problems”
Reviews.Author: maynard7
Reviews.Content: The hotel is fairly new, and I found it attractive. But, it has Technology Gone Wild. You can use the TV and remote control to set the air conditioning, turn the lights off and on (and select mood lighting), tune the TV, watch movies, listen to the radio, among other things. It would be great if it all worked flawlessly, but it doesn't. On two out of my five nights there, all the lights in the room suddenly turned on, waking me up. I guess there's some short-circuit somewhere in my room, but how will they ever find it? To turn on the TV and tune to channel 9 took 12 key presses on the remote control. The TV volume was fine, but when I tried to watch a movie from their online collection, there was no volume. The very helpful girl from the front desk fixed it, but the next day I had the same problem. It would just be better to have equipment that works, instead of making things so complicated. There is no lightweight blanket in the room, only a thick comforter. This requires you to set the air conditioning temperature very low to be able to sleep in comfort. Seems kind of wasteful on their part, since most businesses like to keep energy costs low. The mirror in the bathroom is not in front of you. It's mounted on the wall to the side of the sink. Every time you shave, brush your teeth or put on makeup, you have to lean uncomfortably over the sink and look to your left to see yourself. Because of poor lighting, one side of your face is lit up more than the other, which makes shaving or makeup difficult. They should have mounted the mirror on a hinge so it could swing to a position in front of you. Otherwise, the bathroom is a good size and very attractive. In fact, the shower stall is oversized compared to the rest of the room. Ladies, there's no full-length mirror. There is an utter lack of space to put anything. This was a glaring oversight on the part of the planners at the hotel. This could have been avoided by simply putting the mattress on a platform raised a foot or two off the floor, thereby providing empty space under the bed. Such space is handy and critical in a room of this size. Just being able to slide your suitcase underneath the bed, along with shoes, shopping bags, etc., would be a great help to guests trying not to trip over their belongings. There is a tiny closet next to the bed, with a 10 inch wide pathway to reach it. You have to be on your knees (on the bed) to access the closet. There were four rooms on my floor. The springs that close the doors are so strong that it takes a concious effort to not let your door slam (and some guests don't make that effort). The cleaning woman was the worst offender, making all sorts of noise. There is a new high-rise building going up a block or two away. This may annoy light sleepers, or those who like to sleep late. On most days, though, the noise wasn't that bad. There are 2 free laptops in the lobby to use for internet. This is very valuable, since I didn't see any other place to use the internet in this neighborhood. They apparently have free wireless internet in the rooms, which I didn't use. A warning to people that are using a credit card issued outside of Hong Kong to pay your bill here: The hotel's credit card processing machine will convert the Hong Kong dollars to the currency of the country where your card is issued. This doesn't sound all bad, but they are not using the exchange rate provided by your credit card company. They choose an exchange rate that favors the hotel, and you will end up paying more (interestingly, about enough to cover the fees they pay their bank for accepting credit cards). I spent at least half an hour talking to hotel employees about this, and they even got their bank on the phone to talk to me. I wanted to pay in Hong Kong dollars so that Visa would determine the exchange rate, and the solution the bank came up with is to use the old-fashioned credit card imprinter, rather than the electronic one. I don't appreciate the way they are manipulating the exchange rate to charge more. Everywhere else in Hong Kong I used my Visa card, the sales slip always came up in HK Dollars. At this hotel, nobody knows the button to press on the machine to make that happen. I would urge anyone traveling overseas to always refuse having the sales slip prepared in their home currency, as every time this has been offered to me, it has always been in the merchant's favor, sometimes by as much as US$20. Insist that you be charged in the local currency, and let Visa, MasterCard or American Express determine the exchange rate. This hotel even shows the exchange rate on the receipt, not as the very familiar 7.75 rate between the HK Dollar and the US Dollar, but as the inverse 0.132973. Presenting the exchange rate in this manner makes it impossible to quickly evaluate the exchange rate they are using. Service from the front desk employees is not consistent. Some are much more fluent in English than others. Some are very helpful, and some are not. You'll find the best ones very quickly. My room had a window, but some apparently do not. I think they have a room category called "Lite", and these are the lowest priced rooms with no window. Excellent public transit, as it's only a block from the Sheung Wan Subway Station (from this station, take exit A2, go up stairs to street, turn right and the hotel is about a block away). I took the airport train to Central Station, then it's only one subway station away. No need to take a taxi unless you have lots of luggage. Overall, I found the hotel to be attractive and conveniently located. Although my review may sound negative, I don't want to make the hotel sound like a bad place, because it isn't. It just could have a been a much nicer experience. I would stay there again only if I got a low rate, otherwise I would do some more hotel shopping. I probably would have given it 4 stars out of 5 if it hadn't been for all the problems.

Reviews.Title: “Go Elsewhere! (Seriously, don't bother)”
Reviews.Author: Wentworth21
Reviews.Content: I arrived to a small, EMPTY hallway as it seemed the "concierge" (who was rude and unhelpful) was attending to a personal call outside. When someone finally arrived to help, I was told the elevator was broken. As a result I had to haul my suitcase up 7 flights of stairs! (I kid you not.) Communication between employees takes place through "oh-so-modern" walkie talkies with messages being repeated several times (and in several languages) as no-one can understand each other. The room was TINY. There is no bath (although there is their famous "torrential rain" shower--which switches between ultra hot and ultra cold, not to mention is a complete waste of water.) Their shower TV, which is "cutting edge technology" was broken. I WATCHED several movies but HEARD none of them as their sound system is terrible. There is no view (and the windows hardly open anyway). I could go on, but I think you get the point. The price may be attractive, but there are better places at similar prices in the area. While the concept of a "Technology Hotel" is great, it is NOT executed here.

Reviews.Title: “No windows in single rooms”
Reviews.Author: Worktravel01
Reviews.Content: Please be aware that the single rooms do not have any windows. Tiny rooms when you just need somewhere to sleep are fine but I found it more then a little suffocating to be in a windowless room.

Reviews.Title: “Great Location”
Reviews.Author: SavvyInTheCity
Reviews.Content: I booked a room at Mingle on the Wing for its accessibility to the Ferry Terminal and proximity to the MTR station. As expected, the room was small (as of most hotels in HK) but it was relatively clean. It lived up to my expectations until, I experienced problems with not just the TV remote, the heater but also the fire alarm, Firstly, I had to ring the reception a few times so that they could come up and check our remote control which was only finally repaired on the second night. Then as I was about to take a shower, the water turned cold and I had to get my husband to ring the reception to turn on the heater. In the end, I got tired of waiting and just showered in the cold water. To make matters worse, this happened not just once but twice. Lastly, we were woken up by the fire alarm at ard 10 plus in the morning when it went off. The only consolation was that it was not that early and about time we got up. On the flip side, we really enjoyed the wide selection of movies available when we could not sleep at night. However, our stay would have been a lot more enjoyable if not for the hickups.

Reviews.Title: “Great locatiion - great value”
Reviews.Author: minnowlam
Reviews.Content: This hotel is on a small street but one block from the main Des Veoux Road. We took the airport express train from the airport and then took a cab for $16HK dollars to the hotel. The cabs here are cheap! It's 1/2 block from the Sheun Wan MTR station which is really convenient as you can get almost anywhere on the subway. Subways are extremely clean and safe. The area is safe to walk around late at night as well with a 24hr 7-Eleven variety store on the corner for late night drinks and snacksl. You can walk to the Macau ferry terminal in 5 minutes and to the other ferry terminals in about 10-15 minutes. The staff are friendly and the rooms are clean and compact. I guess for HK standards this is typical - we stayed in a deluxe room on the 4th floor. I would recommend getting an upgraded room as it's a little bigger but by no means large by Canadian standards - just enough to open our two suitcases. The wake up call feature that you can program on the TV is really interesting...TV comes on first and then all the lights and then the phone rings... I would recommend this hotel as it's a great location and great value.

Reviews.Title: “love it!!!”
Reviews.Author: mann01
Reviews.Content: this hotel is recommendable to everyone. Esther the receptionist assisted us very well. She is excellent,she took care of us.to the management of mingle on the wind thank you so much!!! we really enjoyed our vacation. our room was very clean, could not ask for anything

Reviews.Title: “Modern and Cosy”
Reviews.Author: AVCHD
Reviews.Content: We had two rooms, a single room and a twin room. Firstly reception is efficient checked in at 3pm and was quickly into the room. Need $HK500 per room for bond or credit card imprint. Single room was on 5th floor, Twin on 12th floor. My single room had a balcony, very compact bed and bathroom. Literally 30cm between toilet bowl and basin, so its very tight. Shower was strong on 5th floor but weak on the 12th floor. Twin room bathroom was larger however shower area was smaller than single room. Nice LCD screen which has some weird controls, so wont be suprising if you experience some difficulties. However very nice modern renovation, like an ikea style room. Location is just 1 min from Sheung Wan MTR station entrance and 10 mins to HK ferry terminal, however there are stairs so may need to carry heavy luggage. The area isn't too touristy so there arent hawkers around. We were allowed to leave our luggage for an extra 5 hours past checkout for no charge. Wifi unfortunately didn't work on 5th floor, but there are two computers to use on the ground floor. If you need power adaptor they have convertors to lend out. With sleeping, I'm 165cm and I find my feet overhang the bed. They supply toothbrush/paste/razor/cream/slippers. The lighting is very minimal the lighting can cast shadows when you look at yourself in the mirror. One criticism is they need to have hooks for coats behind doors/bath door. However its clean and quiet for a good nights rest. Would come back again good value/location. But might try its other hotel at Tsim Sa Tsui.

Reviews.Title: “Awesome Stay”
Reviews.Author: Cambium
Reviews.Content: I stayed at Mingle on the Wing for four nights when I was in Hong Kong with my girlfriend. I think we got a good deal as we paid only around $60USD for a double. The room was very cozy (or tiny) as there was only enough room for two twin beds (worry not, they were pieced together), a big LCD TV, and our two suitcases. The TV is connected to a central server, and there was a big selection of Hollywood (and Asian) movies, including new releases that you can watch for free. Also, there is free wireless internet in the room. The room itself and the bathroom were exceptionally clean, and we were very happy about. The outlets in the room are not compatible with North American appliances, however, a converter (for the shape only, not for the voltage) can be borrowed at the front desk free of charge. The location of the hotel is also very convenient -- a two-minute walk to the nearest subway station, which is only one subway stop away from Central Station (central Hong Kong). The famous Man Mo Temple is only a few streets away (although there's really nothing to see).

Reviews.Title: “Technical Issues”
Reviews.Author: nanooki
Reviews.Content: Although well located and close to an MTR stop, our stay at Mingle on the Wing could have been better. The rooms are small but cute and and clean. The lobby and the elevator have seen better days. The staff who work there seem a bit sullen except for the night shift guy who's always helpful. They staff also need to brush up on their English language skills to make the stay of guests more comfortable. The whole deal with Mingle is that there's an accent on technological innovation but sadly that all exists on a much lower level than needed for the functioning of this type of hotel. Some kind of message concerning hotel air temperature flashes constantly on the flatscreen TV and a loud alarm goes off. We had to ask the receptionist to come solve this problem a number of times. There are two laptops available for the use of guests but they are not connected to a printer and that really is a problem especially if you are trying to franically print out a boarding pass.

Reviews.Title: “Room was cold!”
Reviews.Author: Ski_Kaos
Reviews.Content: Whilst the staff were all very polite and appeared sincere and concerned, we found the following problems at this hotel: 1. We booked a 5-night stay and EVERY day (yes 5 times) we complained that the room was cold and there was no heater. The first time the receptionist said it would be too hard as they'd have to find a heater factory!!?! I suggested they just go buy a HK$150 heater from a shop, but that seemed to make no sense to him. The staff seemed to rotate to new staff almost every day. The next 3 people over 4 days (to whom we complained about the heating) all seemed very concened that we were cold and assured us they would have the aircon fixed (apparetly the heat output on it was broken, apart from the fact that it had a secondary fault where it would never turn on in the first place without a technician resetting something in the hall cupboard). On the final day one of the earlier staff members said she had previously ordered a technician and didn't know what had happened. She assured us that she would chase it up, ...but it still was not fixed. They probably fixed it the day we checked out, as if that is of any use to us... So all in all we were very cold in our (HK$730/night) room!! Absolutely unforgivable, a backpackers would have provided a cheap and effective heater, so why can't a mid-range hotel do it?? We had to wear long sleeves and long pants when we were not in bed. 2. The room was TINY - shoebox sized. At first I thought this was just a Hong Kong standard but then we moved to a slightly cheaper (and far nicer) hotel very close by and got a room almost 3 times the size for less money and of a higher standard. At Wing On Lok we paid for a "Deluxe Room" as opposed to a standard room, so I expected some space, it was so small that I had to do my morning exercises (push ups, yoga) on the bed! 3. There was no wifi service in our room, despite this "tech-hotel" bragging that wifi is "everywhere" in the hotel. I got zero bars and could not establish a proper connection. To be fair, there was a CAT5 connection but this meant being tied to the (tiny) desk so I could not use my laptop in bed which would have been a lot more comfortable at times. 4. The AV system was still not complete (hence not working at all apart from the TV), despite the hotels advertisement claiming it would be ready for February (we stayed Feb 12-17). There was no DVD played and I could not plug in my MP3 player. 5. The reception staff member when we checked in (late) could not speak more than a few words of English, In addition he had no concept of trying to communicate in other ways (sign language etc..) although the latter seems to be a trait of all HongKongese. 6. Although this did not matter to me, the hotels advert was all about personal service - but there was none of this whatsoever, larger hotels have always been far more personal. Reception couldn't even give (or even sell) me a map of Hong Kong!

Reviews.Title: “Good budget find in a convenient location”
Reviews.Author: Cucques
Reviews.Content: We got a good rate for our room by booking online - it was a four day consecutive rate. HK$490 per night. It was a standard room ie. the basic one. Room - Tiny but we had expected it as this is Hong Kong and we had also chosen the cheapest room, rather than going for a superior, deluxe or otherwise (as we knew we were going to be out most of the time). Basically, we had a queen sized bed which took up most of the room. Having said that, everything was brand new, modern and the room was very clean. The bathroom had a shower (no bathtub), was modern and compact but had enough room. We also had an LCD TV and wifi. Liked the fact that you could switch off the aircon and open the windows. Location - Brilliant - metres away from the A2 exit of Sheung Wan MTR (underground) station. Central is a stroll away too. There are many local cafes in the area for breakfast, laundry/dry cleaning shops, a 7/11 a couple of doors down. HK Airport Express station is a short taxi drive away. Service - Perfectly fine. Overall we thought that the value was good, despite the size of the room, due to the location/convenience and price.
